lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can revise adjectives and categorise them by use (e.g., appearance, personality, physical features).
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Create a class adjective wall. Sort words under categories: looks, feelings, personality. Ask: “Can we describe Sam?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write complete sentences using descriptive adjectives.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Students write 2–3 sentences about a person they know, using a mix of adjectives: “My dad is tall and kind.” Share with a partner.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can pronounce words with the “-ir”, “-er”, and “-ur” sounds correctly.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Dictate: “bird, her, turn.” Students write and identify sound patterns. Then match words to pictures on SB or flashcards.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
